update.description:
* Option to view joints on context menu (desktop) or radial menu (mobile).

* If model doesn't have joints, the option shows disabled on the menu.

* XYZ (red, green, blue) axes represent the joint pose w.r.t. the joint's child link.

* Yellow arrow represents the joint axis, which can be described w.r.t. the child link or to the parent model in case `use_parent_model_frame === true`. (Needs [Gazebo issue #1268](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/1268/joint-visuals-are-not-properly-oriented) fixed to receive flag on joint message. Now `true` by default as most old models have it true.)

* Different joint visuals according to joint type (`revolute`, `revolute2`, `prismatic`, `universal`, `ball`, `screw`, `gearbox`).

![joints7.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/5RMr4M/images/3224281410-joints7.png)
update.title: View joints

content.raw: commit 28e5826
content.html: commit 28e5826

content.raw:
As for making them semi-transparent, Three.js is giving me a hard time... Some parts render on top of others, making it difficult to see the whole joint visual at once. 

I tried a couple of things, including setting the same material we have on [gzmanipulator](#!/osrf/gzweb/src/e8d0efa1396959784d9ff1752b130afedb5b4e4e/gz3d/src/gzmanipulator.js?at=default#cl-125) but it still gets occluded sometimes, I think it has to do with the order elements are added to the scene... Is it really important? :]
content.html:
As for making them semi-transparent, Three.js is giving me a hard time... Some parts render on top of others, making it difficult to see the whole joint visual at once.

I tried a couple of things, including setting the same material we have on gzmanipulator but it still gets occluded sometimes, I think it has to do with the order elements are added to the scene... Is it really important? :]

* Option to view joints on context menu (desktop) or radial menu (mobile).

* If model doesn't have joints, the option shows disabled on the menu.

* XYZ (red, green, blue) axes represent the joint pose w.r.t. the joint's child link.

content.raw: What is a main use case for viewing the joints? If a user enables the joint view and then zooms in, what are they most likely trying to see? I ask in case they may zoom in to get a closer look at the model itself. If we enlarge the joint indicators as they zoom, it may keep the user from being able to see what they're trying to see.
content.html: What is a main use case for viewing the joints? If a user enables the joint view and then zooms in, what are they most likely trying to see? I ask in case they may zoom in to get a closer look at the model itself. If we enlarge the joint indicators as they zoom, it may keep the user from being able to see what they're trying to see.

content.raw: Actually I was wondering about the whole size. Not sure what is ideal here... Thought of maybe scaling them according to the zoom the same way the manipulation handles are scaled, what do you think?
content.html: Actually I was wondering about the whole size. Not sure what is ideal here... Thought of maybe scaling them according to the zoom the same way the manipulation handles are scaled, what do you think?

content.raw:
commit c008c8a

The first time visuals are created, they're added to their child links and stored on the `model.jointVisuals` array.

Hiding removes them from the link, making them invisible.

Showing adds them back to their link, according to the order they were stored. There's a call to `model.getObjectByName` to get the child link here (I guess it is less expensive than `GZ3D.Scene.getByName` because it doesn't go through the whole scene).
content.html:
commit c008c8a

The first time visuals are created, they're added to their child links and stored on the model.jointVisuals array.

Hiding removes them from the link, making them invisible.

Showing adds them back to their link, according to the order they were stored. There's a call to model.getObjectByName to get the child link here (I guess it is less expensive than GZ3D.Scene.getByName because it doesn't go through the whole scene).

update.description:
* Option to view joints on context menu (desktop) or radial menu (mobile).

* If model doesn't have joints, the option shows disabled on the menu.

* XYZ (red, green, blue) axes represent the joint pose w.r.t. the joint's child link.

* Yellow arrow represents the joint axis, which can be described w.r.t. the child link or to the parent model in case `use_parent_model_frame === true`. (Needs [Gazebo issue #1268](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/1268/joint-visuals-are-not-properly-oriented) fixed to receive flag on joint message. Now `true` by default as most old models have it true.)

* Different joint visuals according to joint type (`revolute`, `revolute2`, `prismatic`, `universal`, `ball`, `screw`, `gearbox`).

![joints7.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/5RMr4M/images/3224281410-joints7.png)
update.title: View joints

content.raw:
`getObjectByName` / `getByName` is kind of an expense call, it would be nice to avoid repeatedly calling it

One idea is that we can create the joint visuals the first time, store the visuals in an array variable in `model`, and subsequent calls to this function just toggles the `visible` property of the joint visuals in the array.
content.html:
getObjectByName / getByName is kind of an expense call, it would be nice to avoid repeatedly calling it

One idea is that we can create the joint visuals the first time, store the visuals in an array variable in model, and subsequent calls to this function just toggles the visible property of the joint visuals in the array.
